The velocity gradient tensor for homogeneous, isotropic turbulence (HIT), with explicit consideration of local and non-local effects using a Schur decomposition

Christopher J. Keylock 1Sheffield Fluid Mechanics Group and Department of Civil and Structural Engineering, University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, UK
Abstract

A Schur decomposition of the velocity gradient tensor (VGT) for homogeneous, isotropic turbulence (HIT) is undertaken and its physical consequences examined. This decomposition permits the normal parts of the tensor (represented by the eigenvalues) to be separated explicitly from the non-normal effects. Given the restricted Euler approximation to the VGT dynamics is written in terms of the isotropic part of the pressure Hessian and the invariants of the characteristic equation of the VGT (in turn expressed in terms of the eigenvalues), the non-normal terms are related to the non-local aspects of the dynamics and the anisotropic part of the pressure Hessian. Using a direct numerical simulation of HIT, we show that the norm of the non-normal part of the tensor is of a similar order to the normal part, highlighting the importance of non-local effects. In fact, beneath the discriminant function in a Q‚àíRQR\mbox{Q}-\mbox{R} plot, all enstrophy arises from the non-normal term, meaning that vorticity and intermediate strain eigenvector alignment in this region is an immediate consequence of non-normality. A non-normal term appears in the expressions for both enstrophy and total strain and cancels when calculating the second invariant of the VGT, while the self-amplification of non-normality and the normal straining of non-normality appear in the strain production and enstrophy production equations and cancel when calculating the third invariant. However, these terms are significant for understanding the full VGT dynamics, explaining how flow structures evolve to a disc-like state despite the strain eigenvalues sometimes indicating opposite (rod-like) behaviour, as well as explaining vorticity and strain alignments in HIT.

I Introduction

I.1 Brief overview

This paper is concerned with properties of the velocity gradient tensor (VGT) for incompressible, homogeneous, isotropic turbulence (HIT). This is a classical topic in turbulence fluid mechanics as HIT is the testing ground for a great deal of turbulence theory. A recent review paper by Meneveau (2011) provides a great deal of information on the properties of the VGT and serves as both a basis and a point of departure for this study. The key difference between this study and previous work concerns the form of decomposition of the tensor that underpins the analysis. Conventional studies employ the clearly physically interpretable Hermitian/skew-Hermitian decomposition into strain, ùñ≤ùñ≤\mathsf{S}, and rotation, Œ©sans-serif-Œ©\mathsf{\Omega}, components, with the latter often then modified to a vorticity vector. However, the eigenvalues are also important for delimiting different topological states of the tensor, and therefore there is some history to studying the invariants of the characteristic equation for the VGT. Our approach is to prioritize the eigenvalue-based approach and to then deploy a subsequent Hermitian/skew-Hermitian decomposition. However, the first thing we note is that, just examining the eigenvalues is insufficient. While the Hermitian/skew-Hermitian decomposition gives an additive decomposition of the velocity gradient tensor, ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}:

ùñ†=ùñ≤+Œ©,ùñ†ùñ≤sans-serif-Œ©\mathsf{A}=\mathsf{S}+\mathsf{\Omega}, (1)

to form the equivalent with an eigenvalue-based approach, we need a decomposition of the tensor into a normal tensor, ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B}, (characterized by the eigenvalues) and a non-normal part, ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}, (characterizing the local torques acting on the tensor resulting from tensor asymmetries). Hence, we may write an alternative to (1) as

ùñ†=ùñ°+ùñ¢.ùñ†ùñ°ùñ¢\mathsf{A}=\mathsf{B}+\mathsf{C}. (2)

The tool from matrix algebra we use to accomplish this is the Schur transform (Schur, 1909).

Having commenced our analysis of ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} from this starting point, we can then use the Hermitian/skew-Hermitian decompositions of ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C} to elucidate the relative importance of strain and rotation for both the normal and non-normal parts of the tensor. We use this framework to re-interrogate and shed further light on a number of properties of the VGT.

The well-known Q‚àíRQR\mbox{Q}-\mbox{R} diagram (QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} in our notation) is shown for homogeneous, isotropic turbulence (HIT) at a Taylor Reynolds number of 433 in Fig. 1, with the discriminant function, ŒîLsubscriptŒîùêø\Delta_{L} as a solid line and the six regions that are delimited throughout this study also labelled. The features of this diagram are well-known and of particular prominence is the Vieillefosse tail (Vieillefosse, 1984) that forms a ‚Äòridge‚Äô to the joint distribution function on the positive RAsubscriptùëÖùê¥R_{A} side. The degree of mass along the tail, close to the origin and in the opposite, (Q>0,R>0formulae-sequenceQ0R0\mbox{Q}>0,\mbox{R}>0), quadrant can be shown to be statistically significant features of HIT both with respect to Gaussian, random tensors (Tsinober, 2001) and random tensors constrained to local properties (Keylock, 2017). It was shown by Cantwell that the restricted Euler equations that consider the dynamics of the velocity gradient tensor only in terms of QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} and RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A} (see below) have two possible solutions (Cantwell, 1992):

  • ‚Ä¢

    Given the timescale, t0=1/|QA0|subscriptùë°01superscriptsubscriptQùê¥0t_{0}=1/\sqrt{|\mbox{Q}_{A}^{0}|}, for QA0=0,RA<0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptQùê¥00subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}^{0}=0,\mbox{R}_{A}<0 the solutions evolve to the fixed point, QA=RA=0subscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}=\mbox{R}_{A}=0;

  • ‚Ä¢

    For any other initial conditions the solution evolves towards the Vieillefosse tail, defined as the bottom right quadrant of Fig. 1 along the line ŒîL=0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}=0.

That the majority of points lie close to the origin, or along the Vieillefosse tail, highlights the importance of the restricted Euler approximation. However, it is clearly necessary to go beyond this approach to derive a workable model for the velocity gradient tensor dynamics that includes terms that prevent the mass of the distribution function over-accumulating at the extreme of the Vieillefosse tail. There have been a number of papers that have proposed models for this behavior and these are discussed briefly below. However, a contribution to this area is not the intent of this study, which focuses instead on refining understanding of terms associated with the evolution of the VGT.

Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss summarizes how the velocity gradient tensors for HIT extracted from the Johns Hopkins database used to populate Fig. 1 are distributed over the six regions of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram and the four feasible states for enstrophy production and strain production based on their signs. What is very clear is that the two most frequently occupied regions in terms of their relative occupany, regions 2 and 6, with opposite signs for QAsubscriptùëÑùê¥Q_{A} and RAsubscriptùëÖùê¥R_{A}, are both dominated by positive strain production and enstrophy production. Clearly the relative magnitudes of these terms differ significantly in these two cases to establish the change in sign for RAsubscriptùëÖùê¥R_{A}. The only region where tensors with negative values for both enstophy production and strain production are more likely than tensors with both terms positive is region 1. The opposite region to this (region 4) has a nearly equal probability of the two strain/enstrophy production states, while in the regions adjacent to, but above, the discriminant function (regions 3 and 5) it is seen that the physically feasible combination with different signs for the two production terms is nearly as likely as the case where both are positive. Hence, these latter two regions exhibit intermediate characteristics compared to regions 2 and 4, and 1 and 6, respectively.

I.3 Models for the velocity gradient tensor

The restricted Euler model for the velocity gradient tensor already discussed (Cantwell, 1992) has been followed by a number of studies that have sought to improve the physical representation of the Lagrangian dynamics of the velocity gradient tensor (Girimaji and Pope, 1990; Martin et¬†al, 1998; Chevillard et¬†al, 2008; Wilczek and Meneveau, 2014; Johnson and Meneveau, 2016). These studies have followed a stochastic approach where the unclosed terms in the Lagrangian evolution equation (the deviatoric part of the pressure Hessian and the viscous term) are split into fluctuations that are modelled as Gaussian white noise, and mean quantities conditioned on the velocity gradient tensor itself. Such models result in behaviour in QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} space that is a much better representation of the true PDF than seen in the restricted Euler formalism (see Fig. 6 of Johnson and Meneveau (2016) by way of example).

More related to the theme of this paper is the formulation of the full set of coupled ODEs that describe the Lagrangian evolution of ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} (Martin et¬†al, 1998; Nomura and Post, 1998). Such an approach also benefits from a decomposition of the presure Hessian, ùñßùñß\mathsf{H}, in (4) into isotropic and deviatoric parts (Ohkitani and Kishiba, 1995):

ùñßùñß\displaystyle\mathsf{H} =ùñßi‚Äãs‚Äão+ùñßd‚Äãe‚Äãvabsentsuperscriptùñßùëñùë†ùëúsuperscriptùñßùëëùëíùë£\displaystyle=\mathsf{H}^{iso}+\mathsf{H}^{dev}
ùñßi‚Äãs‚Äãosuperscriptùñßùëñùë†ùëú\displaystyle\mathsf{H}^{iso} =‚àí23‚ÄãQA‚Äãùñ®‚â°13‚Äãtr‚Äã(ùñß)‚Äãùñ®,absent23subscriptQùê¥ùñ®13trùñßùñ®\displaystyle=-\frac{2}{3}\mbox{Q}_{A}\mathsf{I}\equiv\frac{1}{3}\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{H})\mathsf{I}, (13)

where ùñ®ùñ®\mathsf{I} is the 3√ó3333\times 3 identity matrix and the substitution of ùñ∞Asubscriptùñ∞ùê¥\mathsf{Q}_{A} for the trace of the Hessian comes from the Poisson equation for the pressure.

The isotropic term acts to preserve the volume of the fluid element without directional preference, and the deviatoric term includes all the non-local effects from the surrounding flow (hence, requiring an integration over the whole flow). Thus, where ŒîL>0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}>0 and enstrophy dominates total strain, the isotropic part acts to reduce the enstrophy growth rate, so that amplification is either due to stretching, i.e. the enstrophy production tr‚Äã(Œ©A2‚Äãùñ≤A)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê¥2subscriptùñ≤ùê¥\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{A}), or the action of ùñßd‚Äãe‚Äãvsuperscriptùñßùëëùëíùë£\mathsf{H}^{dev}.

In the restricted Euler formulation, working in the frame of reference of the moving fluid and with viscous effects and ùñßd‚Äãe‚Äãvsuperscriptùñßùëëùëíùë£\mathsf{H}^{dev} set to zero, we have just two coupled ODEs that give the evolution of the scalars QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} and RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A} (Cantwell, 1992):

Because there are 8 independent terms in ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} and three scalars are needed to specify orientation in three dimensions (Meneveau, 2011), five orientation-free scalars can be used to determine the system. If we consider the invariants for the strain and rotation, which we indicate with a bracketed superscript, then:

The remaining term needed to close the system is the square of the stretching vector which in its rotation (rather than vorticity form) is V2=‚àí12‚Äãtr‚Äã[(Œ©A‚Äãùñ≤A+ùñ≤A‚ÄãŒ©A)2]superscriptùëâ212trdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê¥subscriptùñ≤ùê¥subscriptùñ≤ùê¥subscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê¥2V^{2}=-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{tr}[(\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}\mathsf{S}_{A}+\mathsf{S}_{A}\mathsf{\Omega}_{A})^{2}]. The following evolution equations may then be derived (Martin et¬†al, 1998):

We revisit the component terms in these equations in the next sections, where they are re-cast and studied from the perspective of the formulation developed in this paper. First, however, we develop our alternate approach to tensorial decomposition and examine some of its implications and consequences.

II A formulation of velocity gradient tensor analysis resolving normal and non-normal effects explicitly

II.1 Tensor non-normality and the Schur transform

The primary innovation in this study is to undertake an additive decomposition of the velocity gradient tensor, ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}, into normal, ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B}, and non-normal, ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}, components before any subsequent decomposition into rotation or straining aspects. This permits us to unpack a number of phenomena commonly lumped together and thereby clarify the behaviour of the tensor. If ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} is normal, then

ùñ†ùñ†‚àó=ùñ†‚àó‚Äãùñ†.superscriptùñ†ùñ†superscriptùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}\mathsf{A}^{*}=\mathsf{A}^{*}\mathsf{A}. (19)

The eigenvalue decomposition is given by

ùñ´‚ÄãŒõ‚Äãùñ´‚àí1=ùñ†,ùñ´sans-serif-Œõsuperscriptùñ´1ùñ†\mathsf{L}\mathsf{\Lambda}\mathsf{L}^{-1}=\mathsf{A}, (20)

where ùñ´ùñ´\mathsf{L} contains the eigenvectors and Œõsans-serif-Œõ\mathsf{\Lambda} is a diagonal matrix of eigenvalues (Œõ1,1=Œª1subscriptŒõ11subscriptùúÜ1\Lambda_{1,1}=\lambda_{1}). We now state the Schur transform (Schur, 1909):

ùñ¥ùñ≥ùñ¥‚àó=ùñ†,superscriptùñ¥ùñ≥ùñ¥ùñ†\mathsf{U}\mathsf{T}\mathsf{U}^{*}=\mathsf{A}, (21)

where ùñ¥ùñ¥\mathsf{U} is unitary and ùñ≥=Œõ+ùñ≠ùñ≥sans-serif-Œõùñ≠\mathsf{T}=\mathsf{\Lambda}+\mathsf{N}, with ùñ≠ùñ≠\mathsf{N} an upper triangular tensor. We note that because the ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i} may contain a conjugate pair (where ŒîL>0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}>0), to ensure ùñ≠ùñ≠\mathsf{N} is upper triangular rather than quasi-upper triangular, a complex Schur decomposition is used throughout this study (Golub and van Loan, 2013). The appendix reviews the distinction between the complex and real forms for the decomposition.

Note that the Schur transform contains a stronger constraint than the eigen decomposition on the form of the rotation matrix. Because ùñ¥ùñ¥\mathsf{U} is unitary, ùñ¥ùñ¥‚àó=ùñ®superscriptùñ¥ùñ¥ùñ®\mathsf{U}\mathsf{U}^{*}=\mathsf{I}, where ùñ®ùñ®\mathsf{I} is the identity matrix, and this means that ùñ¥ùñ¥‚àí1=ùñ®superscriptùñ¥ùñ¥1ùñ®\mathsf{U}\mathsf{U}^{-1}=\mathsf{I} as well. For the eigen decomposition, while ùñ´ùñ´‚àí1=ùñ®superscriptùñ´ùñ´1ùñ®\mathsf{L}\mathsf{L}^{-1}=\mathsf{I}, ùñ´ùñ´‚àó=ùñ®superscriptùñ´ùñ´ùñ®\mathsf{L}\mathsf{L}^{*}=\mathsf{I} is only true when ùñ≥=Œõùñ≥sans-serif-Œõ\mathsf{T}=\mathsf{\Lambda}, i.e. ùñ≠=ùñÆùñ≠ùñÆ\mathsf{N}=\mathsf{O} and, therefore, ùñ´=ùñ¥ùñ´ùñ¥\mathsf{L}=\mathsf{U}. From (20) and (21), when ùñ≠ùñ≠\mathsf{N} is a zero tensor, ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} is normal and described thoroughly by its eigenvalues. It therefore follows that ùñ†ùñ†‚àó‚â†ùñ†‚àó‚Äãùñ†superscriptùñ†ùñ†superscriptùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}\mathsf{A}^{*}\neq\mathsf{A}^{*}\mathsf{A} and ‚Äñùñ≠‚Äñ>0normùñ≠0||\mathsf{N}||>0 are both measures of non-normality and there are a number of papers that give bounds for ‚Äñùñ≠‚Äñnormùñ≠||\mathsf{N}|| given ‚Äñùñ†ùñ†‚àó‚àíùñ†‚àó‚Äãùñ†‚Äñnormsuperscriptùñ†ùñ†superscriptùñ†ùñ†||\mathsf{A}\mathsf{A}^{*}-\mathsf{A}^{*}\mathsf{A}|| (Henrici, 1962; Eberlein, 1965; Lee, 1995). Thus, some ‚Äòresidual‚Äô dynamics exist independent of the eigenvalues of ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} and the advantage of the Schur decomposition is that it moves these effects out of the eigenvectors (orientations) and into a tensor ùñ≠ùñ≠\mathsf{N} that, with the eigenvalues, contributes to ùñ≥ùñ≥\mathsf{T}.

II.2 Normal and non-normal velocity gradient tensors and properties of the second invariant of the velocity gradient tensor

Returning to our alternative additive decomposition postulated in (2), we may now write that:

ùñ°ùñ°\displaystyle\mathsf{B} =\displaystyle= ùñ¥‚ÄãŒõ‚Äãùñ¥‚àóùñ¥sans-serif-Œõsuperscriptùñ¥\displaystyle\mathsf{U}\mathsf{\Lambda}\mathsf{U}^{*} (22)
ùñ¢ùñ¢\displaystyle\mathsf{C} =\displaystyle= ùñ¥ùñ≠ùñ¥‚àó,superscriptùñ¥ùñ≠ùñ¥\displaystyle\mathsf{U}\mathsf{N}\mathsf{U}^{*}, (23)

and this is the key conceptual innovation in this paper. Thus, ùñ†=ùñ°+ùñ¢ùñ†ùñ°ùñ¢\mathsf{A}=\mathsf{B}+\mathsf{C} provides an explicit means to separate the normal and non-normal contributions to the dynamics. That is, we have an additive decomposition into a tensor, ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} containing the dynamics driven by the eigenvalues, which from the restricted Euler formulation are preferentially associated with the local dynamics, and a tensor, ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C} that contains dynamics that are a result of asymmetric structure in the VGT induced by non-local effects.

Taking the rotation and strain tensors for ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}, we have

ùñ°ùñ°\displaystyle\mathsf{B} =ùñ≤B+Œ©Babsentsubscriptùñ≤ùêµsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ\displaystyle=\mathsf{S}_{B}+\mathsf{\Omega}_{B} (24)
ùñ¢ùñ¢\displaystyle\mathsf{C} =ùñ≤C+Œ©C.absentsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂subscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê∂\displaystyle=\mathsf{S}_{C}+\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}. (25)

In terms of the Frobenius norms, non-normality is partitioned equally across ùñ≤Csubscriptùñ≤ùê∂\mathsf{S}_{C} and Œ©Csubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê∂\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}, which means that the constitutive terms for QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} (I.2) may be written as

‚Äñùñ≤A‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê¥2\displaystyle||\mathsf{S}_{A}||^{2} =\displaystyle= ‚Äñùñ≤B‚Äñ2+‚Äñùñ≤C‚Äñ2‚â°‚Äñùñ≤B‚Äñ2+‚ÄñŒ©C‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ2superscriptnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂2superscriptnormsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ2superscriptnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê∂2\displaystyle||\mathsf{S}_{B}||^{2}+||\mathsf{S}_{C}||^{2}\equiv||\mathsf{S}_{B}||^{2}+||\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}||^{2} (26)
‚ÄñŒ©A‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê¥2\displaystyle||\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}||^{2} =\displaystyle= ‚ÄñŒ©B‚Äñ2+‚ÄñŒ©C‚Äñ2‚â°‚ÄñŒ©B‚Äñ2+‚Äñùñ≤C‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ2superscriptnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê∂2superscriptnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ2superscriptnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂2\displaystyle||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||^{2}+||\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}||^{2}\equiv||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||^{2}+||\mathsf{S}_{C}||^{2} (27)

The importance of this is seen with respect to eq. (I.2): the second invariant may now be written as

QA‚â°QB=12‚Äã(‚ÄñŒ©B‚Äñ2‚àí‚Äñùñ≤B‚Äñ2),subscriptQùê¥subscriptQùêµ12superscriptnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ2superscriptnormsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ2\mbox{Q}_{A}\equiv\mbox{Q}_{B}=\frac{1}{2}\left(||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||^{2}-||\mathsf{S}_{B}||^{2}\right), (28)

where the component terms are smaller by a factor of ‚Äñùñ≤C‚Äñ2=‚ÄñŒ©C‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂2superscriptnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê∂2||\mathsf{S}_{C}||^{2}=||\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}||^{2}.

II.3 Some physical aspects of this decomposition

From the above section we see that, in terms of the first two, autonomous ODEs for the VGT dynamics (16,17), we may directly substitute expressions written for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} with those for ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B}. This is physically intuitive because the restricted Euler formulation is a local and inviscid model involving the isotropic part of the pressure Hessian only. Studying the component terms of the second and third invariants when ‚Äñùñ¢‚Äñ‚â†0normùñ¢0||\mathsf{C}||\neq 0 introduces non-local effects into consideration.

A further important aspect of our approach is that the discriminant, ŒîLsubscriptŒîùêø\Delta_{L} has explicit physical consequences in the analysis of rotation, which is not the case when one studies ‚Äñùñ≤A‚Äñnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê¥||\mathsf{S}_{A}|| and ‚ÄñŒ©A‚Äñnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê¥||\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}||. Thus, while the discriminant function partitioning real eigenvalue regions from a conjugate pair and closed streamlines is super-imposed on Fig. 1, the total strain and enstrophy for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} are defined continuously over the ùñ∞Asubscriptùñ∞ùê¥\mathsf{Q}_{A} axis (although, of course, their relative magnitudes change). The advantage of our approach is that because ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} is an eigenvalue-based tensor, ŒîL=0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}=0 demarcates a change in physical behaviour. Mathematically, this arises because the eigenvalues for ùñ≤Bsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mathsf{S}_{B} and Œ©Bsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ\mathsf{\Omega}_{B} are the real and imaginary parts of the eigenvalues for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}. Hence, where ŒîL<0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}<0 there is no imaginary part and we have ‚ÄñŒ©B‚Äñ=0normsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ0||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||=0, i.e. there is no rotation in the normal part of the tensor. Therefore, QB=‚àí12‚Äã‚Äñùñ≤B‚Äñ2subscriptQùêµ12superscriptnormsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ2\mbox{Q}_{B}=-\frac{1}{2}||\mathsf{S}_{B}||^{2} and all enstrophy comes from ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}, a contribution to QBsubscriptQùêµ\mbox{Q}_{B} that is equal to the strain contribution from ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}. As a consequence of ‚ÄñŒ©B‚Äñ=0normsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ0||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||=0, tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)=0trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ2subscriptùñ≤ùêµ0\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B})=0 and the eigenvalues. for RBsubscriptRùêµ\mbox{R}_{B} and RB(S)subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùêµ\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B} are identical. Hence, the third invariant also has a simple expression beneath the discriminant function in this case: RA‚â°RB=RB(S)subscriptRùê¥subscriptRùêµsubscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùêµ\mbox{R}_{A}\equiv\mbox{R}_{B}=\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B}.

Above the discriminant function, while we can no longer equate the values for the third invariant of ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} with those for RB(S)subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùêµ\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B}, we can state that sgn‚Äã(RB(S))=sgn‚Äã(RB)sgnsubscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùêµsgnsubscriptRùêµ\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B})=\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}_{B}). From the eigenvalue structure, it follows that

tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)=Im‚Äã(Œªc)2‚ÄãŒªr,trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ2subscriptùñ≤ùêµImsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëê2subscriptùúÜùëü\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B})=\mbox{Im}(\lambda_{c})^{2}\lambda_{r}, (30)

where the rùëür and cùëêc subscripts indicate the real and conjugate pair eigenvalues for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} (and ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B}). II.4 Evolution equations for the strain and rotation of ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}

In order to determine the terms that yield the difference between ‚àídet‚Äã(ùñ≤A)detsubscriptùñ≤ùê¥-\mbox{det}(\mathsf{S}_{A}) and ‚àídet‚Äã(ùñ≤B)detsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ-\mbox{det}(\mathsf{S}_{B}) in (12) and (29) it is helpful to write down the equations for the Lagrangian evolution of strain and rotation for ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}:

II.7 The second strain eigenvalue and its Lund and Rogers normalization

One property of HIT that was observed in the early simulations was a strong preference for a positive second eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor (Kerr, 1985; Ashurst et¬†al, 1987). This may be inferred from the shape of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram in Fig. 1 and, in particular, the values in Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss that indicate a preference for positive strain production and, thus, two positive eigenvalues. Topologically, this means that flow packets are more prone to evolve to disc-like features than rod-like features.

The Lund and Rogers normalization of the second eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor is given by (Lund and Rogers, 1994):

eA(L‚ÄãR)=3‚Äã6‚ÄãRA(S)(‚àí2‚ÄãQA(S))32,subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥36subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥superscript2subscriptsuperscriptQùëÜùê¥32e^{(LR)}_{A}=\frac{3\sqrt{6}\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}}{\left(-2\mbox{Q}^{(S)}_{A}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}, (44)

II.8 Alignment properties of the vorticity vector and the strain eigenvectors

An important and surprising early result in the study of the velocity gradient tensor was the preferred alignment between the vorticity vector, ùùéAsubscriptùùéùê¥\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A} and the eigenvector for the intermediate eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor (Kerr, 1985; Ashurst et¬†al, 1987; Jimenez, 1992). Our decomposition gives vorticity vectors for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}, ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B}, and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}, respectively, as well as nine possible strain eigenvectors. Thus we introduce the notation that with eiAsuperscriptsubscriptùëíùëñùê¥e_{i}^{A} indicating an eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}, ordered from most positive to most negative, and ùêûiAsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê¥ùëñ\mathbf{e}^{A}_{i} its corresponding eigenvector, we can define, as an example:

Œ∏iA,C=cos‚Å°(ùùéA,ùêûiC),subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê∂ùëñsubscriptùùéùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂ùëñ\theta^{A,C}_{i}=\cos(\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A},\mathbf{e}^{C}_{i}), (48)

as the angle between the vorticity vector for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} and the ith eigenvector for ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}.

One aspect of our decomposition is that because ùñ≤A=ùñ≤B+ùñ≤Csubscriptùñ≤ùê¥subscriptùñ≤ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂\mathsf{S}_{A}=\mathsf{S}_{B}+\mathsf{S}_{C}, we can examine the alignment between ùêûiAsuperscriptsubscriptùêûùëñùê¥\mathbf{e}_{i}^{A}, and ùêûjBsuperscriptsubscriptùêûùëóùêµ\mathbf{e}_{j}^{B} or ùêûkCsuperscriptsubscriptùêûùëòùê∂\mathbf{e}_{k}^{C}. For example,

œïi,jA,B=cos‚Å°(ùêûiA,ùêûjB).superscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëñùëóùê¥ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùêûùëñùê¥superscriptsubscriptùêûùëóùêµ\phi_{i,j}^{A,B}=\cos(\mathbf{e}_{i}^{A},\mathbf{e}_{j}^{B}). (49)

Note that the eigenvalues for ùñ≤Bsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mathsf{S}_{B} are always equal to the real part of the eigenvalues for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}. Hence, as described in section II.3, when above the discriminant function, we will always have a pair of equal eigenvalues, meaning that the second eigenvalue for ùñ≤Bsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mathsf{S}_{B} is not properly defined in regions 1, 2, 3, and 5.

Finally, we may also consider vorticity vector alignments, such as

ŒæA,B=cos‚Å°(ùùéA,ùùéB).superscriptùúâùê¥ùêµsuperscriptùùéùê¥superscriptùùéùêµ\xi^{A,B}=\cos(\boldsymbol{\omega}^{A},\boldsymbol{\omega}^{B}). (50)

Because the eigenvalues for ùùéBsubscriptùùéùêµ\boldsymbol{\omega}_{B} are the imaginary part of the eigenvalues for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}, beneath the discriminant function, in regions 4 and 6, ùùéA=ùùéCsubscriptùùéùê¥subscriptùùéùê∂\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A}=\boldsymbol{\omega}_{C} and ŒæA,C=1superscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂1\xi^{A,C}=1 with ŒæA,Bsuperscriptùúâùê¥ùêµ\xi^{A,B} and ŒæB,Csuperscriptùúâùêµùê∂\xi^{B,C} undefined.

III The Numerical Simulation

This study makes use of velocity gradient tensors extracted from the Johns Hopkins Turbulence Database numerical simulation of forced isotropic turbulence at a Taylor Reynolds number of 433 (Li et¬†al, 2008) as described by Wan et¬†al (2016). The direct numerical simulation is undertaken on a 10243superscript102431024^{3} grid using a pseudo-spectral method. The energy is injected to maintain the total energy in the Fourier modes, and also retaining a wave number magnitude less than or equal to 2 in each mode. The basic properties of the simulation are summarized in Table 3 and a number of other studies have made use of this resource for studying turbulence physics (Wan et¬†al, 2010; Lawson and Dawson, 2015) or for the testing of data post-processing algorithms (Higham et¬†al, 2016).

IV Results: The role of non-normality

IV.1 The importance of non-normal effects

Given our decomposition, ùñ†=ùñ°+ùñ¢ùñ†ùñ°ùñ¢\mathsf{A}=\mathsf{B}+\mathsf{C}, the first thing to establish is the relative importance of the normal and non-normal tensors; clearly if ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C} is small then it is legitimate to approximate the behaviour of ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} with eigenvalue-based formulations. To evaluate this aspect of the behaviour of our decomposition we can define

Œ∫B,CsubscriptùúÖùêµùê∂\displaystyle\kappa_{B,C} =‚Äñùñ°‚Äñ‚àí‚Äñùñ¢‚Äñ‚Äñùñ°‚Äñ+‚Äñùñ¢‚Äñ,absentnormùñ°normùñ¢normùñ°normùñ¢\displaystyle=\frac{||\mathsf{B}||-||\mathsf{C}||}{||\mathsf{B}||+||\mathsf{C}||}, (51)

as a normalized measure of the magnitude of the two tensors. This is shown in Fig. 2 and it is clear from the upper panel that the overall mode for the distribution is slightly negative, with a median close to Œ∫B,C=0subscriptùúÖùêµùê∂0\kappa_{B,C}=0. Hence, the non-normality is as important to the tensor as the part explained by the eigenvalues. Thus, in HIT, asymmetrical forcings on the tensor as a consequence of non-local effects are an important part of the flow dynamics. When the results in Fig. 2 are partitioned by the six regions of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram, we see that for each pair of diagrams for a given QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} state, it is the left-hand variant, with RA<0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}<0, where there is a greater contribution from ‚Äñùñ¢‚Äñnormùñ¢||\mathsf{C}||.

Region 3 is where Œ∫B,CsubscriptùúÖùêµùê∂\kappa_{B,C} is most strongly negative and region 6 is where Œ∫B,CsubscriptùúÖùêµùê∂\kappa_{B,C} is most positive. This latter result is all the more impressive because for ŒîL<0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}<0 (regions 4 and 6), ‚ÄñŒ©B‚Äñ=0normsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ0||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||=0, meaning that in the majority of instances, ‚Äñùñ≤B‚Äñ>‚Äñùñ≤C‚Äñ+‚ÄñŒ©C‚Äñnormsubscriptùñ≤ùêµnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂normsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê∂||\mathsf{S}_{B}||>||\mathsf{S}_{C}||+||\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}||, or ‚Äñùñ≤B‚Äñ>2‚Äã‚Äñùñ≤C‚Äñnormsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ2normsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂||\mathsf{S}_{B}||>2||\mathsf{S}_{C}||. Thus, an eigenvalue-based description of the flow is particularly effective near the Vieillefosse tail, which is consistent with this being an attractor for the dynamics of the restricted Euler (eigenvalue-based) set of equations for the dynamics of the VGT (Cantwell, 1992).

IV.2 The second invariant and non-normality

From (28), we may examine the components of the second invariant with respect to non-normality

Œ∫Q(Œ©)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑŒ©\displaystyle\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)} =‚ÄñŒ©B‚Äñ‚àí‚Äñùñ≤C‚Äñ‚ÄñŒ©B‚Äñ+‚Äñùñ≤C‚Äñabsentnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂normsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂\displaystyle=\frac{||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||-||\mathsf{S}_{C}||}{||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||+||\mathsf{S}_{C}||} (52)
Œ∫Q(S)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ\displaystyle\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} =‚Äñùñ≤B‚Äñ‚àí‚Äñùñ≤C‚Äñ‚Äñùñ≤B‚Äñ+‚Äñùñ≤C‚Äñ.absentnormsubscriptùñ≤ùêµnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂normsubscriptùñ≤ùêµnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂\displaystyle=\frac{||\mathsf{S}_{B}||-||\mathsf{S}_{C}||}{||\mathsf{S}_{B}||+||\mathsf{S}_{C}||}. (53)

Beneath the discriminant function, Œ∫Q(Œ©)=‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑŒ©1\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}=-1 by definition and such results are not shown in the panels for regions (4) and (6) in Fig. 3. Their contribution to the overall distribution function for Œ∫Q(Œ©)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑŒ©\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)} is shown in the top panel, which has a log-scale because of the dominance of the -1 limit. The second panel is on a linear scale and the results for Œ∫Q(Œ©)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑŒ©\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)} are shown as a dotted line and exclude the values at -1, providing a better means to evaluate the overall shape of the distribution.

While an increase in the mean values for Œ∫Q(Œ©)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑŒ©\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)} and decrease for Œ∫Q(S)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} with QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} is very distinct, the differences as a function of the sign of RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A} are more obvious than in Fig. 2. For example, while we anticipate a difference between regions 4 and 6 in their values for Œ∫Q(S)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} from the discussion of Fig. 2, their respective modes of 0.16 and 0.28 indicate this very clearly. In regions 3 and 5, where ŒîL>0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}>0 and QA<0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}<0, we have a positive mode for region 5 at Œ∫Q(S)=0.07superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0.07\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}=0.07 and a mode of Œ∫Q(S)=‚àí0.12superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0.12\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}=-0.12 for region 3. Furthermore, the probability of Œ∫Q(Œ©)<‚àí0.995superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑŒ©0.995\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}<-0.995 is much higher in region 5 at p=0.018ùëù0.018p=0.018 (it is the distribution‚Äôs mode) than in region 3 (p=0.003ùëù0.003p=0.003). This highlights the extent to which the Vieillefosse tail is an attractor for the dynamics as there is a concentration of values lying very close to ŒîL=0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}=0 in region 5, but not region 3.

Where QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, we see that the mode in region 1 for Œ∫Q(Œ©)=0.18superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑŒ©0.18\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}=0.18 is more positive than for region 2 (Œ∫Q(Œ©)=0.12superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑŒ©0.12\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}=0.12), and there is also a stronger tendency for Œ∫Q(S)‚Üí‚àí1‚ÜísuperscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ1\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}\to-1. Hence, a simplified and approximate view of the right-hand side of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram is that Œ∫Q(S)=‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ1\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}=-1 for QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 and Œ∫Q(Œ©)=‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑŒ©1\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}=-1 for QA<0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}<0. In both regions 1 and 2 there are a similar proportion of positive Œ∫Q(S)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} occurrences (8.5% and 7.1%, respectively). In such cases the degree of compression or extension due to ùñ≤Bsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mathsf{S}_{B} is greater than from the non-normal part, on average, implying there is a strong and coherent motion orthogonal to the plane of rotation driven by normal straining. This particular hypothesis is considered in Section VI.5 where we summarize the various alignment properties of the tensor.

IV.3 The third invariant and non-normality

The components of the third invariant are listed and interpreted in Table LABEL:table.terms. In a similar fashion to the non-normal contribution cancelling when evaluating the second invariant because RA=RBsubscriptRùê¥subscriptRùêµ\mbox{R}_{A}=\mbox{R}_{B}, the non-normal and interaction terms appear in a similar fashion in both the strain production (37) and enstrophy production (38) equations. Thus, in this section, we determine the relative significance of non-normal production, RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} and interaction production, tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê∂2subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B}) relative to the two normal terms: normal strain production, RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜ\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}, and normal enstrophy production, tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ2subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B}).

First, we examine the extent to which the sum of the component terms, i.e. RASsubscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥\mbox{R}^{S}_{A} and tr‚Äã(Œ©A2‚Äãùñ≤A)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê¥2subscriptùñ≤ùê¥\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{A}) equates to the sum of the absolute values for each term as a means to assess the extent to which component terms are opposite in sign to RA(S)subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A} and tr‚Äã(Œ©A2‚Äãùñ≤A)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê¥2subscriptùñ≤ùê¥\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{A}):

[RA(S)]‚àósuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥\displaystyle[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*} =RA(S)|RB(S)|+|RC(S)|+|tr‚Äã(ùñ≤C2‚Äãùñ≤B)|absentsubscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥superscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜsuperscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜtrsuperscriptsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂2subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\displaystyle=\frac{\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}}{|\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}|+|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|+|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{S}_{C}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B})|} (54)
[tr‚Äã(Œ©A2‚ÄãSA)]‚àósuperscriptdelimited-[]trsubscriptsuperscriptŒ©2ùê¥subscriptùëÜùê¥\displaystyle[\mbox{tr}(\Omega^{2}_{A}{S}_{A})]^{*} =tr‚Äã(Œ©A2‚ÄãSA)|tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚ÄãSB)|+|RC(S)|+|tr‚Äã(ùñ≤C2‚Äãùñ≤B)|absenttrsubscriptsuperscriptŒ©2ùê¥subscriptùëÜùê¥trsubscriptsuperscriptŒ©2ùêµsubscriptùëÜùêµsuperscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜtrsuperscriptsubscriptùñ≤ùê∂2subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\displaystyle=\frac{\mbox{tr}(\Omega^{2}_{A}{S}_{A})}{|\mbox{tr}(\Omega^{2}_{B}{S}_{B})|+|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|+|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{S}_{C}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B})|} (55)

Figure 4 shows the values for [RA(S)]‚àósuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*} as a function of the region of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptùëÑùê¥subscriptùëÖùê¥Q_{A}-R_{A} diagram and the signs of RA(S)subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A} and for tr‚Äã(Œ©A2‚ÄãSA)trsubscriptsuperscriptŒ©2ùê¥subscriptùëÜùê¥\mbox{tr}(\Omega^{2}_{A}{S}_{A}). The results reflect those seen in Fig. 2 in that for each pair of panels, departures from [RA(S)]‚àó=¬±1superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥plus-or-minus1[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*}=\pm 1 are always more probable on the RA<0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 side.

We might have inferred from Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss that the cause of the different degree of importance on the RA<0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 side of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram was related to the negative strain production - positive enstrophy production state, i.e. the extension of rod-like structures. However, we see in Fig. 4 that the state where both terms are positive is also more likely to have a significant non-normal contribution to [RA(S)]‚àósuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*} than is the case on the RA>0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}>0 side. That it is the strain production that is preferentially influenced by non-local effects is shown by comparing the results for [RA(S)]‚àósuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRùëÜùê¥[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*} with those for [tr(Œ©A2ùñ≤A]‚àó[\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{A}\mathsf{S}_{A}]^{*} in Fig. 5, where a large proportion of the values are at [tr(Œ©A2ùñ≤A]‚àó=1[\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{A}\mathsf{S}_{A}]^{*}=1. The exceptions to this are regions 1 and 5, where the two states with positive strain production are particularly prone to non-normal interactions. This bias in favour of non-normal interactions for strain production is expected based on the pressure Hessian appearing in the dynamic equation for total strain, but not enstrophy. Hence, it is an indirect mechanism that leads to an impact of non-normality on enstrophy production. For example, we see from Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss that negative strain production and enstrophy production is particularly prevalent in region 1. Hence, dissipation by the compression of rod-like turbulent structures (Tsinober, 2001) in this region, itself affected significantly by non-normality for strain production (Fig. 4) provides a means to induce non-normal effects on the enstrophy production.

IV.4 The four production terms

The probability curves for our four production terms are given in Fig. 6 conditioned on both the sign of the term and the regions of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram. As explained in section II.3, sgn‚Äã(RB(S))=sgn‚Äã(RA)sgnsuperscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜsgnsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)})=\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}_{A}) and sgn‚Äã(tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B))=‚àísgn‚Äã(RA)sgntrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµsgnsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}))=-\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}_{A}), while tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)=0trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ0\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B})=0 beneath the discriminant function (regions 4 and 6). Thus, the basic properties of these terms is known from our formulation.

While QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 is a useful visualization tool, it is of less obvious physical significance than ŒîL>0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}>0. However, it is fairly clear from Fig. 6 that apart from the obvious difference that there is no curve for tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) where ŒîL<0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}<0, the other curves exhibit a clearer difference between positive and negative QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} states than positive and negative ŒîLsubscriptŒîùêø\Delta_{L} states. For example, in regions 5 and 6 we see there is very little difference in the distribution functions for RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜ\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} and RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}, while there is a small decrease in the probability of negative values for tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}) as we move from region 5 to region 6. Hence, the change in the nature of the balance between strain production and enstrophy production and, thus, RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A} as a flow parcel moves from region 5 to region 6 is driven almost entirely by the existence of a negative contribution from tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) in region 5 and its absence in region 6. Otherwise, we see that the positive and negative values for RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} approximately cancel while the interaction term is biased towards positive values. Thus, we may simplify the strain production and enstrophy production balance in region 6 to being about positive strain production and positive stretching of non-normality by the normal strain tensor. Region 5 has the same terms acting with similar strength, with an additional negative contribution by the enstrophy production term. In regions 3 and 4 we see something close to the mirror image of the behaviour in regions 5 and 6 for the two normal terms, but with the distributions for the non-normal and interaction terms similar to those in regions 5 and 6. However, RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} favours positive values more strongly in regions 3 and 4 than in regions 5 and 6, while tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}) is less biased towards positive values, particularly in region 4.

Regions 1 and 2 have qualitatively different properties to the other cases:

  • ‚Ä¢

    The magnitude of the values for RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜ\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} is drastically reduced on average in both regions 1 and 2;

  • ‚Ä¢

    The magnitude of the values for tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) increases greatly on average in both regions 1 and 2;

  • ‚Ä¢

    In region 1, it is negative values for the interaction term, tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}), that are more probable, the only region in the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram where this is the case. The positive values are also reduced in magnitude compared to other regions;

  • ‚Ä¢

    In region 1 we see positive contributions from RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} with magnitudes exceeding all other terms. This is the only region where this is the case and means that where QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, RA>0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}>0 states are driven by both positive non-normality and negative normal enstrophy production;

  • ‚Ä¢

    In region 2, there is an increase in the bias towards positive values for both RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} and tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}), although the magnitude of these positive contributions is still dominated by normal enstrophy production, meaning that where QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, RA<0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 states are driven by this positive enstrophy production.

It was suggested in the previous subsection that in region 1, compression of vortex tubes would be a means by which non-normal strain production and enstrophy production is significant when both strain production and enstrophy production are negative. How this arises is explained by these features of region 1. Because normal strain production is positive, its eigenvalues can only lead to disc-like structures in this region. Hence, for rod-like structures to develop, the combined negative effect of the non-normal and interaction term must be sufficient to result in RA(S)<0superscriptsubscriptRùê¥ùëÜ0\mbox{R}_{A}^{(S)}<0, and the frequency of negative values for the interaction term has already been commented on, and appears to be driving such occurrences. This is confirmed below when we look at the joint properties of these terms, although the extent of this effect is mediated by the positive values for the non-normal term. Given that tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) is negative and large in magnitude, compression of these tubes that result from non-normal effects is readily facilitated.

IV.5 Joint behaviour of the production terms

Further information on the structure of the production terms can be gleaned from their joint behaviours and we show RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜ\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} against the combined behaviour of the non-normal and interaction terms (Fig. 7), tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) against the combined behaviour of the non-normal and interaction terms (Fig. 8), and disaggregate the latter terms into RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} and tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}), respectively (Fig. 9). Each panel in these three figures displays the results for each region of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram as a difference from the overall joint PDF for all regions combined, with darker contours a sink for that region of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram, and lighter contours an excess. The logarithmic nature of the bins used to generate the PDFs results in a series of ‚Äúbutterfly‚Äù plots of varying nature.

In Fig. 7, the region that most clearly violates the anticipated symmetry is region 1, where the excess is essentially at RB(S)=0superscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜ0\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}=0, with the bias in the non-normal and interaction terms towards negative values, as anticipated in the previous section. Where RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜ\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} has larger positive values, in the bottom-right region of this panel, RC(S)+tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜtrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}+\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}) is also strongly negative, counteracting any tendency from the eigenvalues to drive positive strain production. In Fig. 8 we see that this negative bias in RC(S)+tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜtrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}+\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}) is strongly correlated with the negative values for normal enstrophy production. We can determine which of the non-normal and interation terms are driving these negative values from Fig. 9, where we note it is the interaction term that, as already anticipated in the previous section, has a very strong bias to negative values. The non-normal term is very important to the production in region 1, but exhibits both strongly negative and positive contributions with a very weak correlation to the interaction term. To quantify these statements, we determine the cases that lie in region 1 and where tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)<0trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ0\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B})<0 and then we calculate the mean difference in the absolute production quantities. We find that

  • ‚Ä¢

    |tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)|‚àí|RC(S)|¬Ø=0.027¬Øtrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ0.027\overline{|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B})|-|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|}=0.027;

  • ‚Ä¢

    |tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)|‚àí|tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)|¬Ø=0.027¬Øtrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµtrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ0.027\overline{|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B})|-|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B})|}=0.027;

  • ‚Ä¢

    |RB(S)|‚àí|RC(S)|¬Ø=‚àí0.006¬ØsuperscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜsuperscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ0.006\overline{|\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}|-|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|}=-0.006; and,

  • ‚Ä¢

    |RB(S)|‚àí|tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)|¬Ø=‚àí0.005¬ØsuperscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜtrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµ0.005\overline{|\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}|-|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B})|}=-0.005.

That is, the normal enstrophy production is greater in magnitude on average than either the non-normal or interaction terms, both of which are greater in magnitude than the normal strain production when the interaction term is negative, as may be inferred from Fig. 6.

With the exception of region 1, the butterfly plots in Fig. 7 exhibit a general symmetry with the combined term strongly biased towards positive values and the sign of RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRùêµùëÜ\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} given by physical constraints, resulting in a positive correlation between the terms on the right-hand side and a negative correlation on the left-hand side. This explains why strain production is highest around the Vieillefosse tail (regions 5 and 6). The results in Fig. 8 exhibit strong correlations in all four legitimate regions with the sign of this correlation, opposite in sense to that in Fig. 7 because of the opposite sign for tr‚Äã(Œ©B2‚Äãùñ≤B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}). Clearly, region 1 is the unusual case again, with a strong positive correlation in the negative-negative part of this panel. It is also the case that although region 3 exhibits a strong positive correlation in the positive-positive part of the panel, there is a deficit for large values of normal enstrophy production, as can be inferred from the weak marginal distribution for this term in Fig. 6. The consequence of this is that for positive values of normal enstrophy production, the combined effect of the non-normal and interaction terms outweighs that of the normal term in region 3. An examination of the relevant panel in Fig. 9 shows that, in contrast to region 1, it is RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} that drives this behaviour, which is not obvious from the marginal distributions in Fig. 6.

Given the highly structured nature of the normal terms, the joint distribution function for the non-normal and interaction terms produces a rather more unique signature in each region than is seen in Figs. 7 and 8. This is summarized in the textual descriptions in Fig. 9, where region 1 is the only region where the net average effect of these two terms is negative. We also see that the interaction term tends to dominate the non-normal contribution on the positive RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A} side of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram, with the non-normal term dominant on the negative side.

Rather than merely looking at the location of the areas of excess as is summarized in the text boxes in Fig. 9, we also looked at which term tends to dominate in each of these areas. We extracted the major excess areas for each region in Fig. 9 and determined the mean of the difference of the absolute values, |tr‚Äã(Œ©C2‚Äãùñ≤B)|‚àí|RC(S)|¬Ø¬Øtrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©2ùê∂subscriptùñ≤ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptRùê∂ùëÜ\overline{|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B})|-|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|}, in each case. These values are given in Table LABEL:table.prod_C_interact. Thus, we can see that the non-normal term is dynamically important in region 1, as has already been reported and is seen in Fig. 6, but the interaction term is more significant both because the sign of the excess areas is where tr(Œ©C2ùñ≤B<0\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}<0 and because there is a bias towards the case where both terms are negative (55:45). In contrast, in region 2, we see that the dominant area of excess is where both terms are positive, but that in this region, the interaction term is clearly dominant. In region 3 we see that the strength of the positive net effect comes from a dominant interaction term where both terms are positive, and the magnitude of the non-normal term exceeding that for the interaction term on average where the former is positive and the latter is negative. This latter situation is what also drives the weak positive net behaviour in region 4, while in regions 5 and 6 it is that the interaction term is positive and much greater in magnitude on average than the non-normal term irrespective of the sign for the latter.

IV.6 The square of the vortex stretching term

As described in (40), we decomposed the nonlinear vortex stretching term, V2superscriptùëâ2V^{2}, into four component terms (one purely normal term, ùñµB‚ÄãB=Œ©B‚Äãùñ≤B+ùñ≤B‚ÄãŒ©Bsubscriptùñµùêµùêµsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµsubscriptùñ≤ùêµsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùêµ\mathsf{V}_{BB}=\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}+\mathsf{S}_{B}\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}, a purely non-normal term, ùñµC‚ÄãCsubscriptùñµùê∂ùê∂\mathsf{V}_{CC}, and two interaction terms, ùñµB‚ÄãCsubscriptùñµùêµùê∂\mathsf{V}_{BC} and ùñµC‚ÄãBsubscriptùñµùê∂ùêµ\mathsf{V}_{CB}). In addition, we defined Va‚Äãb‚Äãssubscriptùëâùëéùëèùë†V_{abs} to highlight that the products of the interaction terms with the non-normal term can be negative. While the magnitude of tr‚Äã(ùñµB‚ÄãC‚ÄãùñµC‚ÄãC)trsubscriptùñµùêµùê∂subscriptùñµùê∂ùê∂\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{BC}\mathsf{V}_{CC}) exhibits the expected opposite behaviour in Fig. 10g, the key difference is the symmetric nature of these distributions compared to Fig. 10h. This means that it is the high QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} regions that show the greater effect of the two product terms in Fig. 10a and Table LABEL:table.V2.

Given the relatively small contribution from these terms and the symmetric nature of the tr‚Äã(ùñµB‚ÄãC‚ÄãùñµC‚ÄãC)trsubscriptùñµùêµùê∂subscriptùñµùê∂ùê∂\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{BC}\mathsf{V}_{CC}) product term, in particular, it is the two squared interaction terms that dominate vortex stretching. For regions 3 and 5, while the values are smaller, this is still the most important single term on average, with [tr‚Äã(ùñµC‚ÄãB2)/Va‚Äãb‚Äãs]50‚àº0.4similar-tosubscriptdelimited-[]trsuperscriptsubscriptùñµùê∂ùêµ2subscriptùëâùëéùëèùë†500.4[\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{CB}^{2})/V_{abs}]_{50}\sim 0.4.
