In summary, and in common with the analysis of the production terms, analysis of vortex stretching has shown the dynamical importance of the interaction between normal and non-normal terms, particularly below the discriminant function where the non-normal term remains small and the normal term is undefined as a consequence of the absence of a normal rotation tensor in this region. The negative skewness to the distribution for tr‚Äã(ùñµC‚ÄãB‚ÄãùñµC‚ÄãC)trsubscriptùñµùê∂ùêµsubscriptùñµùê∂ùê∂\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{CB}\mathsf{V}_{CC}) in regions 1 and 2, in particular, means that for QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, the value for V2superscriptùëâ2V^{2} is less effectively determined by the sum of the squared terms, i.e. tr‚Äã(ùñµB‚ÄãB2+ùñµB‚ÄãC2+ùñµC‚ÄãB2+ùñµC‚ÄãC2)trsuperscriptsubscriptùñµùêµùêµ2superscriptsubscriptùñµùêµùê∂2superscriptsubscriptùñµùê∂ùêµ2superscriptsubscriptùñµùê∂ùê∂2\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{BB}^{2}+\mathsf{V}_{BC}^{2}+\mathsf{V}_{CB}^{2}+\mathsf{V}_{CC}^{2}), than is the case below the discriminant function as can be seen in Table LABEL:table.V2.

V Results: The second eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}

The well-known properties of the Lund and Rogers normalization, eA(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A}, are shown in the upper panel of Fig. 11. The tendency for HIT to form disc-like structures is very evident. Sub-dividing the results by region of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram shows that this tendency is driven by regions 2, 5 and 6. However, given that RA>0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}>0 in regions 1, 5 and 6, and positive strain production, ‚àídet‚Äã(ùñ≤A)>0detsubscriptùñ≤ùê¥0-\mbox{det}(\mathsf{S}_{A})>0 means there are two positive strain eigenvalues, it is not intuitive that it is region 2, rather than region 1, where eA(L‚ÄãR)‚Üí1‚ÜísubscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}\to 1. Noting in section IV.1 that only ‚àº8%similar-toabsentpercent8\sim 8\% of data in regions 1 and 2 have Œ∫Q(S)>0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0, then this property of HIT can be understood when we look at eA(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A} conditioned on the sign of Œ∫Q(S)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} (the grey lines in Fig. 11). Where Œ∫Q(S)>0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0 (solid grey lines) we see the anticipated behaviour of a tendency for eA(L‚ÄãR)‚Üí+1‚ÜísubscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}\to+1 in region 1 and eA(L‚ÄãR)‚Üí‚àí1‚ÜísubscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}\to-1 in region 2. Consequently, the reason for the observed behaviour is that the non-normal contribution to the strain tensor exceeds the normal part and exhibits a very different distribution to that driven by the eigenvalues. Given that it is in regions 1 and 2 that enstrophy exceeds strain and, according to the Q-criterion (Hunt et¬†al, 1988; Dubief and Delcayre, 2000), is where there is a coherence to flow motion, we can see that non-normality is crucial for the evolution of disc-like structures. Given our earlier result that contributions from ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C} do not feature in the restricted Euler formulation of the VGT dynamics, it is clear that the anistropic contributions from the pressure Hessian are extremely important for this evolution of disc-like structures. From Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss, region 2 is frequented more than twice as often as region 1 (26.5% to 11.1%), which also helps explain the strong tendency for eA(LR‚Üí1e^{(LR}_{A}\to 1 seen in the top-most panel.

From Fig. 3 we can determine that Œ∫Q(S)>0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0 occurs for 39.4%, 68.6%, 60.6% and 82.2% of occurrences in regions 3 to 6, respectively. In Fig. 11 it is region 5 where Œ∫Q(S)>0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0 has the strongest tendency to produce values at eA(L‚ÄãR)=1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}=1, while everywhere but region 1, one finds that Œ∫Q(S)<0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}<0 preferentially leads to positive values for eA(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A}. The complex case is region 4, where the normal contribution to the strain is strongly dominant, but has a mode at eA(L‚ÄãR)=‚àí0.08subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥0.08e^{(LR)}_{A}=-0.08, indicating that here the preferred state is close to isotropy (the ‚Äúblob‚Äù in the terminology of Kuo and Corrsin (1972)); any tendency to form disc-like structures is a consequence of the non-normal dominant cases in this region.

V.1 The disaggregation of the Lund and Rogers normalization of the strain rate tensor

We established in Section II.7 that eA(L‚ÄãR)=eB|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A}=e^{(LR)}_{B|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} and it is the component terms on the right-hand side that we investigate in this section. However, we first examine

e|A|(L‚ÄãR)=|eA(L‚ÄãR)|eB|A(L‚ÄãR)|+|eC|A(L‚ÄãR)|+|eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)||,subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{|A|}=\left\lvert\frac{e^{(LR)}_{A}}{|e^{(LR)}_{B|A}|+|e^{(LR)}_{C|A}|+|e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}|}\right\rvert, (56)

to gain an insight into how common it is for some of these component terms to have the opposite sign to e|A|(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{|A|} and the relative magnitude of such effects as a function of QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} and RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A}. Given the tendency in HIT for eA(L‚ÄãR)‚Üí1‚ÜísubscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}\to 1 and that, as explained in section II.7, sgn‚Äã(eB|A(L‚ÄãR))=sgn‚Äã(RA)sgnsubscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥sgnsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{sgn}(e^{(LR)}_{B|A})=\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}_{A}), we expect that e|A|(L‚ÄãR)‚â†1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{|A|}\neq 1 more often in regions 2, 3, and 4, where RA<0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}<0. This is the case, particularly where ŒîL>0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}>0 in regions 2 and 3 (and to a certain extent in region 1 where RA>0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}>0 but QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0). Indeed, with the exception of region 1, the overall result that about 25% of tensors in HIT have e|A|(L‚ÄãR)=1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{|A|}=1 is simply not representative of the behaviour of the individual regions.

It follows from these results that the joint distribution function for the normal term, eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A}, and the combined non-normal and interaction terms, eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}, should exhibit the strongest probability gradient across the frontier eB|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=¬±1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥plus-or-minus1e^{(LR)}_{B|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=\pm 1 where both eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A} and eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} are positive, with positive values for eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A} indicating we are in region 1, 5 or 6. This tendency is clear from this joint distribution function in Fig. 13a.

In this panel we see that where eB|A(L‚ÄãR)<0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}<0, the combined behaviour of the non-normal and interaction terms behaves with some degree of symmetry about eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=0, although with a bias towards positive values as might be expected from the global result of a tendency for eA(L‚ÄãR)‚Üí1‚ÜísubscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}\to 1. Therefore, positive values for eA(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A} arise even when eB|A(L‚ÄãR)<0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}<0 as a consequence of the action of the non-normal and interaction terms as we have already shown in a less direct fashion from the conditioning on Œ∫Q(S)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} in Fig. 11.

For positive eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A} we see little symmetry about eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=0. Negative values for the combined term highly improbable with the exception of the limit of eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=‚àí1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=-1. Hence, while there is a weak mechanism for positive eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A} to result in negative eA(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A}, it is rather different in nature and strength to the inverse case. From an inspection of Fig. 13b, this state is most probably realised by eC|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{C|A}=0, eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=‚àí1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=-1, again indicating the importance of the interaction term. That there is a peak to the distribution function for eB|A(L‚ÄãR)>0.5subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0.5e^{(LR)}_{B|A}>0.5 in Fig. 13a that is clearly separated from the dominant ridge along eB|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}=0 highlights that for positive eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A} both the normal and the other terms are interacting to produce eA(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A} values that tend to 1. This may be contrasted with the negative eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A} region where there is a much weaker tendency to converge on a particular value for eA(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A}. That there is a good degree of symmetry to Fig. 13b about eC|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{C|A}=0 indicates that irrespective of the values for eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}, there is no preferred contribution from eC|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C|A}. Hence, the term driving the positive bias in values for eA(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A} is the interaction term, eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}.

Some of the patterns described above are more readily discerned by extracting conditional distributions from the joint PDF, which are shown in Fig. 14. The different normalization between panels (a) and (b) permits the relative and absolute nature of the these conditional distributions to be evaluated. Note, for example, that when eB|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}=0 (black line), the mode of the distribution for the non-normal and interaction terms is 0.5, leading to eA(L‚ÄãR)=0.5subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥0.5e^{(LR)}_{A}=0.5. On the other hand, when eB|A(L‚ÄãR)=0.5subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0.5e^{(LR)}_{B|A}=0.5 (solid grey line), all values for 0‚â§eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)‚â§0.50subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥0.50\leq e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}\leq 0.5 are of similar probability, with the mode at eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=0.5subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥0.5e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=0.5 slightly larger than that at eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=0 and, thus eA(L‚ÄãR)=1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}=1 somewhat more likely for these conditions than eA(L‚ÄãR)=0.5subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥0.5e^{(LR)}_{A}=0.5. Where eB|A(L‚ÄãR)=‚àí0.5subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0.5e^{(LR)}_{B|A}=-0.5 (dashed grey line), the tendency for positive values for eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} alluded to above is also clear, providing a mechanism to bias the distribution for eA(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥e^{(LR)}_{A} towards positive values.

The symmetry about eC|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{C|A}=0 in Fig. 14c can be seen in the similar nature of the values for p‚Äã(eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)|[eC|A(L‚ÄãR)=¬±0.5])ùëùconditionalsubscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥plus-or-minus0.5p(e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}|[e^{(LR)}_{C|A}=\pm 0.5]). Figure 14d highlights the extent to which the mass of the joint distribution is concentrated along eC|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{C|A}=0 and both the lower panels show the strongly bimodal nature of p‚Äã(eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)|[eC|A(L‚ÄãR)=0])ùëùconditionalsubscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥0p(e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}|[e^{(LR)}_{C|A}=0]), with maxima at 0 and 1. Hence, if we reduce the effect of eC|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C|A} to a negligible, stochastic perturbation, these two modes provide the end-member states for the eB|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{B|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=1 frontier in the positive-positive quadrant of Fig. 13a.

V.2 Results conditioned on QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} states

In order to explore these results further, we look at joint PDFs similar to Fig. 13 conditioned on the different regions of QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} space, which are shown in Fig. 15. While the behaviour in regions 1 and 2 (QA>0subscriptùëÑùê¥0Q_{A}>0) is dominated by gradients in eB|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}=0, this cannot be said of the other regions that all behave very differently. Regarding eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A}, it is regions 5 and 6 where this term generates eA(L‚ÄãR)=1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}=1 values as might be anticipated from the earlier analysis showing the importance of the normal tensor in this region. It is region 3 where the normal term generates eA(L‚ÄãR)=‚àí1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}=-1 on its own, and where the strong frontier shows that all terms combine to give this result. Hence, when eB|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}=0, there is a strong positive bias for the non-normal and interaction term that drives a eA(L‚ÄãR)=1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}=1 response. Region 5 has a concentration of values along and near to the frontier in the positive quadrant where the terms interact to give eA(L‚ÄãR)=1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}=1, while region 4 can lead to eA(L‚ÄãR)=‚àí1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}=-1, but the dominant behaviour is for eB|A(L‚ÄãR)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}=0 and for positive values to emerge on average because of the strong positive bias for eC|A(L‚ÄãR)+eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}. Another final means to generate eA(L‚ÄãR)=‚àí1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{A}=-1 is from the combined effect of the non-normal and interaction terms in regions 1 and 2 when the normal term is expressed most weakly.

The structure of the ordinate in Fig. 15 is unpacked in Fig. 16 where we can again see a great variation in structure of the joint PDFs. Region 1 is particularly interesting as the distributions exhibits a ridge with a 90¬∞bend so that in addition to a global maximum at the origin, we see that eC|A(L‚ÄãR)=+1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{C|A}=+1 and eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=‚àí1subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥1e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=-1 have high probability. Such a complex behaviour is not anticipated from the behaviour of eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A}, meaning that in this region, it is the non-normal and the interaction terms rather than the normal term that are driving the topological states as could be discerned in Fig. 11. The complex behaviour is explained in Fig. 17, where the joint PDFs for eC|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C|A} and eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} in regions 1 and 2 are further conditioned on the sign for Œ∫Q(S)superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}. The relatively rare states where Œ∫Q(S)>0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0 (the bottom row of panels) have a weaker contribution from the straining of ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}. This is reflected by the PDFs in regions 1 and 2 exhibiting little variance on the eC|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C|A} axis and with a typical value for eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} with a sign opposite to that for RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A}. However, when Œ∫Q(S)<0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}<0 (top row of panels), there is a dominance of the interaction term in region 2 and the non-normal term in region 1. Hence, in region 2, the strong tendency for the eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} distribution to dominate and to peak close to +1 for Œ∫Q(S)>0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0 is reinforced by the situation for the Œ∫Q(S)<0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}<0 case. In contrast, the two states act orthogonally in region 1, giving the 90¬∞bend to the joint PDF, with the maximum along eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)=0,eC|A(L‚ÄãR)>0formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥0subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥0e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=0,e^{(LR)}_{C|A}>0 due to the mere ‚àº8%similar-toabsentpercent8\sim 8\% of cases where Œ∫Q(S)>0superscriptsubscriptùúÖùëÑùëÜ0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0.

The QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram exhibits a concentration of values in regions 2 and 6 as shown in Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss. We have already seen in Fig. 15 that the tendency to disc-like structures in region 6 is driven firstly by eB|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{B|A} and then by the combined interaction of all terms. Figure 15 shows that region 2 also contributes effectively to this tendency to form disc-like structures, but is about eC,B|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖùê∂conditionalùêµùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} solely, or its interaction with eC|A(L‚ÄãR)subscriptsuperscriptùëíùêøùëÖconditionalùê∂ùê¥e^{(LR)}_{C|A} rather than the normal term.

In summary, there is a bias towards RA>0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}>0 states in the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram as shown in Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss and our approach highlights that the organization of the straining part of the normal tensor is constrained to be greater or equal to zero on this half of the diagram. However, this bias (54.6:45.4) is insufficient to explain the strong tendency to form disc-like structures. Our decomposition shows that this state emerges in a variety of different ways in different parts of QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} space as summarized in Table LABEL:table.LRsummary, and that the overall behaviour is dominated by the normal and interaction terms, with the non-normal term making, on average a weak contribution. However, in region 1, the non-normal term is of particular importance. It is also clear from both 15 and LABEL:fig.eLRB_C1_C2_regions that our decomposition of this space into six regions is justified; while the topological analysis of this space prioritizes positive and negative values for ŒîLsubscriptŒîùêø\Delta_{L} over the sign of QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}, our results for the QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 regions in particular are very different in nature.

VI Results: Vorticity vector and strain eigenvector alignments

VI.1 The existing relations for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}

As is well known, and is shown in Fig. 18, ùùéAsubscriptùùéùê¥\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A} is typically most strongly aligned with ùêû2Asubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê¥2\mathbf{e}^{A}_{2}. If we extract the cases where Œ∏iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 (i.e. ¬±10‚àòplus-or-minussuperscript10\pm 10^{\circ}), we obtain the results shown in Fig. 19. What is particularly notable in this figure is the high proportion of Œ∏iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 occurrences in regions 2 and 6 (‚àº36%similar-toabsentpercent36\sim 36\% in both cases), the two regions that HIT occupies preferentially relative to random, synthetic tensors with appropriate bounds on their non-normality (Keylock, 2017). This relative occupancy is 1.4 times, and 1.2 times higher than is the case for all tensors (without conditioning on region of occurrence) as shown in Fig. 19. Overall, 81% of cases where Œ∏iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 were for Œ∏2A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥2\theta^{A,A}_{2}, with 16% for Œ∏1A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{1}, and the propensity for alignment with Œ∏1A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{1} and Œ∏3A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥3\theta^{A,A}_{3} dictated by the sign of RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A} where ŒîL>0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}>0 and dominated by Œ∏1A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{1} below the discriminant function. Region 3 is the only part of the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram where Œ∏2A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥2\theta^{A,A}_{2} alignments are secondary.

VI.2 Vorticity-vorticity alignments

The decomposition into components derived from ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C} provides insights into the Œ∏iA,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignments discussed above. First, we examine the mutual vorticity vector alignments, above the discriminant function (because below it, ŒæA,C=1superscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂1\xi^{A,C}=1 everywhere). Figure 20 shows that immediately above the discriminant function, a strong tendency for the vorticity vector for ŒæA,C‚Üí1‚Üísuperscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂1\xi^{A,C}\to 1 is retained. However, when QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 this is a weaker effect, with a stronger alignment for ŒæA,Bsuperscriptùúâùê¥ùêµ\xi^{A,B}. The accompanying curves for ŒæB,Csuperscriptùúâùêµùê∂\xi^{B,C} show that there is very limited strong alignment between ùùéBsuperscriptùùéùêµ\boldsymbol{\omega}^{B} and ùùéCsuperscriptùùéùê∂\boldsymbol{\omega}^{C}, meaning there are two distinct sets of vorticity vectors in the positive QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} regions depending on these alignments.

When we condition these distributions on Œ∏iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 (i.e. ¬±10‚àòplus-or-minussuperscript10\pm 10^{\circ}) and then seek cases where ŒæA,B>0.985superscriptùúâùê¥ùêµ0.985\xi^{A,B}>0.985 and ŒæA,C>0.985superscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂0.985\xi^{A,C}>0.985, we obtain the results seen in Fig. 21. The percentages in each panel indicate the efficiency by which strong Œ∏iA,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignments lead to strong ŒæA,Bsuperscriptùúâùê¥ùêµ\xi^{A,B} or ŒæA,Csuperscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂\xi^{A,C} alignments. Given that such values are at 100% for ŒæA,Csuperscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂\xi^{A,C} where ŒîL<0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}<0, there is a clear decrease in this propensity as QAsubscriptQùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A} increases. However, there is a major difference between region 5, which adjoins the Vieillefosse tail, and region 3, with the former approximately twice as effective at retaining strong alignments between the vorticity vectors for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}.

It is clear from Fig. 20 that in regions 3 and 5, ŒæA,Csuperscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂\xi^{A,C} dominates the strong alignments and this is clearly the case in Fig. 21, not only for where Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985, but also for where Œ∏1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985 in region 3. However, an important contrast between Fig. 21 and Fig. 19 can be detected in region 3 in that the number of significant alignments for ŒæA,Bsuperscriptùúâùê¥ùêµ\xi^{A,B} and ŒæA,Csuperscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂\xi^{A,C} is far fewer for cases where Œ∏1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985, despite these cases being more numerous in Fig. 19. Hence, the observed Œ∏1A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{1} alignments in region 3, and the low percentages in regions 1 and 2 show that mutual vorticity alignment is a less important explanation for the Œ∏iA,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignments than is the case in regions 4, 5, and 6.

In regions 1 and 2 of Fig. 21 we see that any degree of excess for Œ∏2A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥2\theta^{A,A}_{2} compared to Œ∏1A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{1} (region 2) or Œ∏3A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥3\theta^{A,A}_{3} (region 1) is much less than is seen in Fig. 19 - the opposite scenario to region 3. It is also the case that ŒæA,Bsuperscriptùúâùê¥ùêµ\xi^{A,B} alignments completely dominate for Œ∏1A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{1} and Œ∏3A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥3\theta^{A,A}_{3} alignments. Thus, while mutual vorticity alignments are relatively rare where QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, there is a clear difference regarding the types of alignments structures that occur: alignment between ùùéAsubscriptùùéùê¥\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A} and the largest or smallest strain eigenvector retains structure between ùùéAsubscriptùùéùê¥\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A} and ùùéBsubscriptùùéùêµ\boldsymbol{\omega}_{B} - it is a consequence of local interactions. In contrast, while local interactions are still relevant for alignments with the intermediate strain eigenvector, it is here than non-local interactions, as signified by ŒæA,Csuperscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂\xi^{A,C} alignments, are most important.

VI.3 Vorticity and strain alignments for ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}

Figure 22 shows the distributions for Œ∏iB,BsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùêµùêµ\theta_{i}^{B,B}, Œ∏iB,CsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùêµùê∂\theta_{i}^{B,C}, Œ∏iC,BsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùê∂ùêµ\theta_{i}^{C,B}, and Œ∏iC,CsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùê∂ùê∂\theta_{i}^{C,C}, and there are several points of interest:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Strong alignments for particular terms are more probable where RA>0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}>0;

  • ‚Ä¢

    Because of the structure of ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B}, for ŒîL>0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}>0, Œ∏1B,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùêµ1\theta^{B,B}_{1} drives the alignments for RA<0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 and Œ∏3B,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùêµ3\theta^{B,B}_{3} where RA>0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}>0;

  • ‚Ä¢

    The Œ∏2C,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùê∂2\theta^{C,C}_{2} alignment is so dominant in regions 4 and 6 that probabilities are shown on a logarithmic axis;

  • ‚Ä¢

    Strong alignments for Œ∏2C,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùê∂2\theta^{C,C}_{2} and Œ∏1C,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùêµ1\theta^{C,B}_{1} for ŒîL<0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}<0 are replaced by strong alignments for either Œ∏1B,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùêµ1\theta^{B,B}_{1} or Œ∏3B,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùêµ3\theta^{B,B}_{3}, and also Œ∏2C,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùê∂2\theta^{C,C}_{2} where ŒîL>0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}>0 and QA<0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}<0 and then a clear dominance for Œ∏1B,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùêµ1\theta^{B,B}_{1} or Œ∏3B,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùêµ3\theta^{B,B}_{3} where QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0;

  • ‚Ä¢

    Where they are defined, Œ∏1B,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùê∂1\theta^{B,C}_{1} and Œ∏3B,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùê∂3\theta^{B,C}_{3} have clear maxima at ¬±45‚àòplus-or-minussuperscript45\pm 45^{\circ}; if this is rather strictly the case as happens in region 5, then the mode for Œ∏2B,C‚Üí0‚ÜísubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùê∂20\theta^{B,C}_{2}\to 0, while in the other regions the mode for Œ∏2B,C‚Üí1‚ÜísubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùê∂21\theta^{B,C}_{2}\to 1;

  • ‚Ä¢

    In all regions, the modes for Œ∏3C,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùêµ3\theta^{C,B}_{3} and Œ∏1C,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùê∂1\theta^{C,C}_{1} are closer to orthogonal rather than aligned.

Results regarding strong alignments for these cases conditioned on strong alignments for Œ∏iA,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ\theta^{A,A}_{i} are given in Fig. 23, where the numbers in each panel are the sum of the values in that panel and the percentages relate directly to those in Fig. 19: the sum of the percentages in a row of Fig. 23 equals the percentages in Fig. 19, with the exception of regions 4 and 6, where the very small contributions from strong Œ∏3A,AsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉ3ùê¥ùê¥\theta_{3}^{A,A} alignments have been excluded. It is notable that the sum of the values in the panels for regions 4 to 6 tend to exceed 1.0. That is, for a given tensor more than one vorticity vector - strain eigenvector pair is strongly aligned. It is also the case that in these regions, nearly all tensors exhibit a strong alignment for Œ∏2C,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùê∂2\theta^{C,C}_{2} when Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985. Given that ŒæA,C=1superscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂1\xi^{A,C}=1 for regions 4 and 6 and the majority of alignments arise for Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985, we have a physical explanation for the second eigenvector alignment here: it is driven by non-normal vorticity alignment, coupled to a strong alignment between the second eigenvector of the non-normal strain tensor and the second eigenvector for ùñ≤Asubscriptùñ≤ùê¥\mathsf{S}_{A} with co-alignment with the second eigenvector for ùñ≤Bsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mathsf{S}_{B} also arising in a number of cases. Thus, while the analysis in the previous sections has highlighted the weak effects of non-normality in region 6, in particular, regarding strain tensor effects, because there is no normal rotation tensor in this region, non-normality plays a critical part in enstrophy production because ŒæA,C=1superscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂1\xi^{A,C}=1.

In regions 1 and 2, there are not only fewer cases where Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 compared to Œ∏3A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥30.985\theta^{A,A}_{3}>0.985 (region 1) and Œ∏1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985 (region 2), but the conversion rate of an Œ∏iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 alignment to one for another vorticity vector - strain eigenvector is more efficient for Œ∏1A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{1} and Œ∏3A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥3\theta^{A,A}_{3} at 37% and 50%, respectively, compared to 19% for Œ∏2A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥2\theta^{A,A}_{2}. For example, in region 2, 0.11√ó30.9=3.40.1130.93.40.11\times 30.9=3.4% for Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 is less than double 0.37√ó5.2=1.90.375.21.90.37\times 5.2=1.9% for Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985, despite the six times higher proportion of Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 instances. For Œ∏1A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{1} and Œ∏3A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥3\theta^{A,A}_{3}, the dominant alignment is for Œ∏iB,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùêµùëñ\theta^{B,B}_{i}, with the value for iùëñi equating to that in the Œ∏iA,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignment. Similar alignments are also important where Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 in regions 1 and 2. Thus, normal vorticity-strain interactions generated by local effects are the most important where QA>0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 and the overall result of Œ∏2A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥2\theta^{A,A}_{2} dominating the alignment structure is really (in terms of direct effects) a consequence of the high values for Œ∏2C,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùê∂2\theta^{C,C}_{2} in region 6 where normal vorticity does not exist.

The only real role played by the interaction terms are the Œ∏1C,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùêµ1\theta^{C,B}_{1} alignments seen in regions 3, 4, and 6 where Œ∏1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985 . From the bottom row of Fig. 22 it can be seen that while the mode for this curve lies close to 1, the peak is an order of magnitude smaller than that for Œ∏2C,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùê∂2\theta^{C,C}_{2} and it is clear that when Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 this term is of minor importance. Hence, the non-normal vorticity vector aligning with the leading strain eigenvector for ùñ≤Bsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mathsf{S}_{B} is important for Œ∏1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985, although that the sums of the alignments in regions 4 and 6 are much greater than 1 shows that there is a co-alignment between the first eigenvector of ùñ≤Bsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mathsf{S}_{B} and the second for ùñ≤Csubscriptùñ≤ùê∂\mathsf{S}_{C} in these regions. Clearly, therefore, the co-alignment between ùêû1Bsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµ1\mathbf{e}^{B}_{1} and ùêû1Asubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê¥1\mathbf{e}^{A}_{1} must be stronger than that for ùêû2Csubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} and ùêû2Asubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê¥2\mathbf{e}^{A}_{2} to produce this result.

VI.4 Strain-strain eigenvector alignments

We can observe clear structure in the mutual strain alignments, œïi,jA,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëñùëóùê¥ùêµ\phi_{i,j}^{A,B}, œïi,jA,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëñùëóùê¥ùê∂\phi_{i,j}^{A,C}, and œïi,jB,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëñùëóùêµùê∂\phi_{i,j}^{B,C}, which are summarized by the modes for each distribution function in Fig. 24. In essence, regions 1 and 2 exhibit a perfect alignment between ùêûiAsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê¥ùëñ\mathbf{e}^{A}_{i} and ùêûiCsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂ùëñ\mathbf{e}^{C}_{i}, while for regions 4 and 6 there is a close to perfect alignment between ùêûiAsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê¥ùëñ\mathbf{e}^{A}_{i} and ùêûiBsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµùëñ\mathbf{e}^{B}_{i}, that is particularly the case for the latter. In region 3 we see a mutual alignment for œï3,3A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï33ùê¥ùê∂\phi_{3,3}^{A,C}, but with the other two eigenvectors aligning with each other such that different tensors have strong œï1,1A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï11ùê¥ùê∂\phi_{1,1}^{A,C}, œï1,2A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï12ùê¥ùê∂\phi_{1,2}^{A,C}, œï2,1A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï21ùê¥ùê∂\phi_{2,1}^{A,C} and œï2,2A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï22ùê¥ùê∂\phi_{2,2}^{A,C} alignments. This behaviour is inverted in the œïi,jA,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëñùëóùê¥ùêµ\phi_{i,j}^{A,B} results, with a strong alignment for œï1,1A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï11ùê¥ùêµ\phi_{1,1}^{A,B}, and different tensors having strong œï2,2A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï22ùê¥ùêµ\phi_{2,2}^{A,B}, œï2,3A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï23ùê¥ùêµ\phi_{2,3}^{A,B}, œï3,2A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï32ùê¥ùêµ\phi_{3,2}^{A,B} and œï3,3A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï33ùê¥ùêµ\phi_{3,3}^{A,B} alignments. Region 5 might be expected to be the mirror image of region 3 and this is approximately the case for the œïi,jA,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëñùëóùê¥ùêµ\phi_{i,j}^{A,B} results. However, the œïi,jA,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëñùëóùê¥ùê∂\phi_{i,j}^{A,C} results are much more similar to those for regions 1 and 2 with alignments at œïi=jA,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëñùëóùê¥ùê∂\phi_{i=j}^{A,C}.

The consequences of these alignments between the ùêûiAsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê¥ùëñ\mathbf{e}^{A}_{i} and ùêûiBsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµùëñ\mathbf{e}^{B}_{i} and ùêûjCsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂ùëó\mathbf{e}^{C}_{j} strain tensors for the mutual relation between the ùêûiBsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµùëñ\mathbf{e}^{B}_{i} and ùêûjCsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂ùëó\mathbf{e}^{C}_{j} is shown in the bottom panel of Fig. 24. In region 4, œï1,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï12ùêµùê∂\phi_{1,2}^{B,C} is aligned well with the other ùêûjCsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂ùëó\mathbf{e}^{C}_{j} (i‚àà{1,3}ùëñ13i\in\{1,3\}) at 45‚àòsuperscript4545^{\circ} to the ùêûiBsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµùëñ\mathbf{e}^{B}_{i}. A similar result exists for the other regions where RA<0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 (regions 2 and 3), although it is less coherent, with a weaker attraction to 45‚àòsuperscript4545^{\circ} and (small) residual orientations for œï2,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï22ùêµùê∂\phi_{2,2}^{B,C} and œï3,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï32ùêµùê∂\phi_{3,2}^{B,C}. Region 1 is, in turn, similar to these regions with the exception that, as a consequence of RA>0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}>0, the dominant alignment is œï3,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï32ùêµùê∂\phi_{3,2}^{B,C} not œï1,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï12ùêµùê∂\phi_{1,2}^{B,C}. Regions 5 and 6 are very similar to one another: As with region 4, a mode at 45‚àòsuperscript4545^{\circ} is strongly expressed, but in contrast, rather than just a strong alignment for œï1,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï12ùêµùê∂\phi_{1,2}^{B,C}, two discrete sets of points exist with strong alignments for both œï1,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï12ùêµùê∂\phi_{1,2}^{B,C} and œï2,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œï22ùêµùê∂\phi_{2,2}^{B,C}.

Similar results to these but conditioned on Œ∏iA,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignments are shown in Fig. 25. In terms of the Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 cases in the central column our first result is that the mutual strain alignments are much more important in regions 1 and 2 (0.54 and 0.58 of 6.6% and 30.9%) than the vorticity-strain alignments in Fig. 23 (0.19 and 0.11 of 6.6% and 30.9%), with the opposite the case in regions 3 to 6 where QA<0subscriptQùê¥0\mbox{Q}_{A}<0. Hence, we have the somewhat counterintuitive result that in enstrophy dominant regions, mutual strain alignments are of particular prominence for explaining vorticity-strain alignments. However, the reason is clearly a combination of ŒæA,C=1superscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂1\xi^{A,C}=1 for ŒîL<0subscriptŒîùêø0\Delta_{L}<0, while vorticity-vorticity alignments are more complex in regions 1 and 2 (Fig. 20), as well as the mutual alignments for œïi=jA,Csubscriptsuperscriptitalic-œïùê¥ùê∂ùëñùëó\phi^{A,C}_{i=j} for regions 1 and 2 in Fig. 24b.

For the Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 cases we see that ùêû3Bsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµ3\mathbf{e}^{B}_{3} and ùêû2Csubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} are aligned in region 1 and ùêû1Bsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµ1\mathbf{e}^{B}_{1} and ùêû2Csubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} in regions 2 and 3. In regions 4 to 6, two sets of points arise with either alignments between ùêû1Bsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµ1\mathbf{e}^{B}_{1} and ùêû2Csubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} or ùêû2Bsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµ2\mathbf{e}^{B}_{2} and ùêû2Csubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2}. Such results for Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 are consistent with the patterns seen in Fig. 24c, with the exception of region 4. However, in regions 3 to 6 in particular, mutual strain alignments are more clearly expressed for the Œ∏1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985 and Œ∏3A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥30.985\theta^{A,A}_{3}>0.985 cases, and here the results are readily explained by the sign of RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A}, as they are for the Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 situation for regions 1 and 2: where RA>0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}>0, ùêû3Bsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµ3\mathbf{e}^{B}_{3} and ùêû2Csubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} are aligned; while, where RA<0subscriptRùê¥0\mbox{R}_{A}<0, ùêû1Bsubscriptsuperscriptùêûùêµ1\mathbf{e}^{B}_{1} and ùêû2Csubscriptsuperscriptùêûùê∂2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} are aligned.

VI.5 Summary

A summary of the results in this section regarding the nature of the Œ∏2A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥2\theta^{A,A}_{2} alignment, in particular, is provided in Fig. 26. As noted in the caption for this figure, the description for each region concerns only one alignment if it much more frequent than the next most common, i.e. Œ∏2A,A‚â´Œ∏1A,Amuch-greater-thansubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥2subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{2}\gg\theta^{A,A}_{1}, while both are described if the difference in relative frequencies is more minor, as arises in regions 3 and 4. All told 81% of the Œ∏iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥ùëñ0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 alignments were for Œ∏2A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥2\theta^{A,A}_{2}, with, in turn, 38% and 37% of these instances occuring in regions 2 and 6, respectively. Thus, focusing on these two regions in the first instance:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Region 2 - All three strain eigenvectors for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} are aligned very closely with those with the same order for ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}. There is then two ways that the Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 state is generated: a direct route resulting from this strain eigenvector state combined with the Œ∏2C,CsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùê∂2\theta^{C,C}_{2} alignment; and, an indirect route where the Œ∏1B,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùêµùêµ1\theta^{B,B}_{1} alignment and the œïi=jA,C=1subscriptsuperscriptitalic-œïùê¥ùê∂ùëñùëó1\phi^{A,C}_{i=j}=1 state, combines with the alignment between the leading eigenvector for ùñ≤Bsubscriptùñ≤ùêµ\mathsf{S}_{B} and the intermediate eigenvector for ùñ≤Csubscriptùñ≤ùê∂\mathsf{S}_{C}.   • ‚Ä¢

    Region 4 - As with region 6, ŒæA,C=1superscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂1\xi^{A,C}=1 and, combined with alignments for Œ∏2C,CsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉ2ùê∂ùê∂\theta_{2}^{C,C} generates the Œ∏2A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥2\theta^{A,A}_{2} structure in the typical way. The different aspect regarding the dynamics in this region is that the Œ∏1A,AsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥1\theta^{A,A}_{1} alignments are more strongly driven by the term, Œ∏1C,BsubscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùêµ1\theta^{C,B}_{1} - the alignment between the vorticity vector for ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C} and the leading strain eigenvector for ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} (a similar indirect mechanism to region 3 is also possible).

VII Conclusion

A radical interpretation of our approach to the additive decomposition of the velocity gradient tensor, ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} into normal and non-normal tensors, ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B} and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}, is to state that while strain production takes place everywhere, enstrophy production does not occur beneath the discriminant function. Instead, from Table LABEL:table.terms, we have either the self-amplification of non-normality, or the normal straining of non-normality acting as a source of enstrophy production beneath the discriminant function. However, that these terms also act as an equal source for strain production means that in regions 4 and 6, (beneath the discriminant function) the third invariant for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} (RAsubscriptRùê¥\mbox{R}_{A} in our notation and simply R conventionally) is just the strain production for ùñ°ùñ°\mathsf{B}.

As there is no normal rotation tensor in these regions, there is a perfect alignment between the vorticity vectors for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} and ùñ¢ùñ¢\mathsf{C}, i.e. ŒæA,C=1superscriptùúâùê¥ùê∂1\xi^{A,C}=1. From Fig. 23 we see that when Œ∏2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê¥ùê¥20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985, i.e. there is a strong alignment between the vorticity vector and the eigenvector for the intermediate strain eigenvalue for ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}, there is an accompanying high frequency of occurrences where Œ∏2C,C>0.985subscriptsuperscriptùúÉùê∂ùê∂20.985\theta^{C,C}_{2}>0.985. The consequence of this ‚Äúnon-normal‚Äù alignment is important throughout all the QA‚àíRAsubscriptQùê¥subscriptRùê¥\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} regions, but is crucial beneath the discriminant function where non-normality is the only source for enstrophy. This, coupled to the high proportion of the time that the flow spends in region 6 explains the alignment between vorticity and the intermediate eigenvector.

The importance of the non-local, non-normal contributions to the dynamics explains the difficulty of applying eigenvalue-focused thinking to the dynamics of complex systems such a turbulence. In a set of landmark papers in the 1990s it was shown that the difficulties of treating hydrodynamic stability in terms of the instability of the eigenvalues of the linearized problem could be overcome using pseudospectra (Reddy et¬†al, 1993; Trefethen et¬†al, 1993), aspects of which characterize the tensor non-normality (Trefethen and Embree, 2005). It was something of a surprise to fluid mechanics when the first direct numerical simulations of HIT showed a preferential alignment between the vorticity vector and the eigenvector for the second eigenvalue of the strain tensor rather than the first eigenvalue (Kerr, 1985; Ashurst et¬†al, 1987). Our Schur decomposition-based approach to VGT dynamics clarifies this matter because much of the interesting dynamics resides in either the non-normal terms (the alignment between the non-normal vorticity and the second eigenvector of the non-normal straining) or is in the interaction between normal and non-normal effects (production by normal straining of the non-normal term). Clearly, these terms are not captured by the eigenvalues of ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A}, highlighting that, as with hydrodynamic stability, looking beyond the eigenvalues is crucial. The advantage of the Schur transform in this respect is that the non-normality, ùñ≠ùñ≠\mathsf{N} is projected into the Schur matrix where it can be treated in a similar way to the eigenvalues, ŒõŒõ\Lambda. Hence, we could define ùñ°=ùñ¥‚ÄãŒõ‚Äãùñ¥‚àóùñ°ùñ¥sans-serif-Œõsuperscriptùñ¥\mathsf{B}=\mathsf{U}\mathsf{\Lambda}\mathsf{U}^{*} and ùñ¢=ùñ¥ùñ≠ùñ¥‚àóùñ¢superscriptùñ¥ùñ≠ùñ¥\mathsf{C}=\mathsf{U}\mathsf{N}\mathsf{U}^{*}. Thus, the rotations matrix, ùñ¥ùñ¥\mathsf{U} retains a unitary form irrespective of the degree of non-normality. In contrast, the eigenvalue decomposition projects the non-normality into the departure of the eigenvectors from a unitary form, making it harder to directly compare normal (local) and non-normal (non-local) effects.

It is only really along the Vieillefosse tail that normal effects, in particular, normal straining, dominate the dynamics. This helps explain the success of the restricted Euler model (Cantwell, 1992) in approximating the dynamics of the VGT, but the more complex behaviour in region 1, in particular, demonstrates the difficulty of understanding the non-local effects that predominate without considering both the eigenvalues and the non-normal contributions. This work defines a suite of quantities that can serve as a new basis for evaluting existing models for the dynamics of the VGT (Wilczek and Meneveau, 2014; Johnson and Meneveau, 2016), and perhaps for formulating new models of this type.

Appendix A Complex and real Schur transforms

The Schur transform (Schur, 1909) may be implemented in a complex or a real form, which we distinguish with bracketed superscripts c and r in this appendix:

ùñ†ùñ†\displaystyle{}\mathsf{A} =ùñ¥(c)‚Äãùñ≥(c)‚Äãùñ¥(c)‚Å£‚àóabsentsuperscriptùñ¥ùëêsuperscriptùñ≥ùëêsuperscriptùñ¥ùëê\displaystyle=\mathsf{U}^{(c)}\mathsf{T}^{(c)}\mathsf{U}^{(c)*}
=ùñ¥(r)‚Äãùñ≥(r)‚Äãùñ¥(r)‚Å£‚àó.absentsuperscriptùñ¥ùëüsuperscriptùñ≥ùëüsuperscriptùñ¥ùëü\displaystyle=\mathsf{U}^{(r)}\mathsf{T}^{(r)}\mathsf{U}^{(r)*}. (57)

For the complex Schur decomposition or, equivalently, a real Schur decomposition of a tensor with real eigenvalues, the Schur matrix, ùñ≥(c)=Œõ(c)+ùñ≠(c)superscriptùñ≥ùëêsuperscriptsans-serif-Œõùëêsuperscriptùñ≠ùëê\mathsf{T}^{(c)}=\mathsf{\Lambda}^{(c)}+\mathsf{N}^{(c)}, may be decomposed into a diagonal matrix of eigenvalues, diag‚Äã(Œõ(c))=Œª1,‚Ä¶,Œª3diagsuperscriptsans-serif-ŒõùëêsubscriptùúÜ1‚Ä¶subscriptùúÜ3\mbox{diag}(\mathsf{\Lambda}^{(c)})=\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{3} and an upper triangular matrix, ùñ≠(c)superscriptùñ≠ùëê\mathsf{N}^{(c)} that characterizes the non-normality of ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} (Golub and van Loan, 2013) as described in the main text of this paper. Hence, as we adopted the complex decomposition, we wrote (without the superscripts)

ùñ†ùñ†\displaystyle{}\mathsf{A} =ùñ°(c)+ùñ¢(c)absentsuperscriptùñ°ùëêsuperscriptùñ¢ùëê\displaystyle=\mathsf{B}^{(c)}+\mathsf{C}^{(c)}
ùñ°(c)superscriptùñ°ùëê\displaystyle{}\mathsf{B}^{(c)} =ùñ¥(c)‚ÄãŒõ(c)‚Äãùñ¥(c)‚Å£‚àóabsentsuperscriptùñ¥ùëêsuperscriptsans-serif-Œõùëêsuperscriptùñ¥ùëê\displaystyle=\mathsf{U}^{(c)}\mathsf{\Lambda}^{(c)}\mathsf{U}^{(c)*}
ùñ¢(c)superscriptùñ¢ùëê\displaystyle\mathsf{C}^{(c)} =ùñ¥(c)‚Äãùñ≠(c)‚Äãùñ¥(c)‚Å£‚àó.absentsuperscriptùñ¥ùëêsuperscriptùñ≠ùëêsuperscriptùñ¥ùëê\displaystyle=\mathsf{U}^{(c)}\mathsf{N}^{(c)}\mathsf{U}^{(c)*}. (58)

However, if one wishes to impose that ùñ°,ùñ¢‚àà‚Ñúùñ°ùñ¢\mathsf{B},\mathsf{C}\in\Re, but ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} has complex eigenvalues, then the real Schur transform should be adopted. In which case, ùñ≥(r)superscriptùñ≥ùëü\mathsf{T}^{(r)} has a quasi-upper triangular, rather than triangular form, with the conjugate pair forming a 2√ó2222\times 2 Jordan block, which complicates the decomposition in (58). In the case of a normal tensor, where ‚Äñùñ≠(r)‚Äñ=0normsuperscriptùñ≠ùëü0||\mathsf{N}^{(r)}||=0, the eigenvalue-like tensor for the real decomposition, Œõ(r)superscriptsans-serif-Œõùëü\mathsf{\Lambda}^{(r)} is defined to be equal to the real Schur tensor, ùñ≥(r)superscriptùñ≥ùëü\mathsf{T}^{(r)}:

ùñ≥(r)=Œõ(r)=(‚Ñú‚Å°(Œªm,n)sgn‚Äã(œá)‚Äã|‚Ñë‚Å°(Œªm,n)|0‚àísgn‚Äã(œá)‚Äã|‚Ñë‚Å°(Œªm,n)|‚Ñú‚Å°(Œªm,n)000Œª‚Ñì),superscriptùñ≥ùëüsuperscriptsans-serif-ŒõùëüsubscriptùúÜùëöùëõsgnùúísubscriptùúÜùëöùëõ0sgnùúísubscriptùúÜùëöùëõsubscriptùúÜùëöùëõ000subscriptùúÜ‚Ñì\mathsf{T}^{(r)}=\mathsf{\Lambda}^{(r)}=\biggl{(}\begin{smallmatrix}\Re(\lambda_{m,n})&\mbox{sgn}(\chi)|\Im(\lambda_{m,n})|&0\\ -\mbox{sgn}(\chi)|\Im(\lambda_{m,n})|&\Re(\lambda_{m,n})&0\\ 0&0&\lambda_{\ell}\end{smallmatrix}\biggr{)}, (59)

where the subscripts, m,nùëöùëõm,n and ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell indicate the positions of the conjugate pair eigenvalues and the real eigenvalue, respectively. The parameter œáùúí\chi ensures that the signs of the imaginary part are aligned correctly

œá={1ifTm,n(r)>Tn,m(r)‚àí1ifTm,n(r)‚â§Tn,m(r)\chi=\biggl{\{}\begin{smallmatrix}1&\mbox{if}&T^{(r)}_{m,n}>T^{(r)}_{n,m}\\ -1&\mbox{if}&T^{(r)}_{m,n}\leq T^{(r)}_{n,m}\end{smallmatrix} (60)

We then may proceed as follows:

  1. 1.

    Determine the eigenvalues of ùñ†ùñ†\mathsf{A} (a conjugate pair and a real-valued eigenvalue);

  2. 2.

    Perform a real-valued Schur decomposition, locate the Jordan block and denote these positions as mùëöm and nùëõn where m<nùëöùëõm<n and m,n‚àà{1,2,3}ùëöùëõ123m,n\in\{1,2,3\};

  3. 3.

    Complete the Jordan block, ùñ©ùñ©\mathsf{J} and insert it, and Œª‚ÑìsubscriptùúÜ‚Ñì\lambda_{\ell}, into the correct locations in a 3√ó3333\times 3 zero matrix to form Œõ(r)superscriptsans-serif-Œõùëü\mathsf{\Lambda}^{(r)}, as shown in (59);

  4. 4.

    Define ùñ≠(r)=ùñ≥(r)‚àíŒõ(r)superscriptùñ≠ùëüsuperscriptùñ≥ùëüsuperscriptsans-serif-Œõùëü\mathsf{N}^{(r)}=\mathsf{T}^{(r)}-\mathsf{\Lambda}^{(r)}. We may then reconstruct using

    ùñ°(r)superscriptùñ°ùëü\displaystyle{}\mathsf{B}^{(r)} =ùñ¥(r)‚ÄãŒõ(r)‚Äãùñ¥(r)‚Å£‚àóabsentsuperscriptùñ¥ùëüsuperscriptsans-serif-Œõùëüsuperscriptùñ¥ùëü\displaystyle=\mathsf{U}^{(r)}\mathsf{\Lambda}^{(r)}\mathsf{U}^{(r)*}
    ùñ¢(r)superscriptùñ¢ùëü\displaystyle\mathsf{C}^{(r)} =ùñ¥(r)‚Äãùñ≠(r)‚Äãùñ¥(r)‚Å£‚àó;absentsuperscriptùñ¥ùëüsuperscriptùñ≠ùëüsuperscriptùñ¥ùëü\displaystyle=\mathsf{U}^{(r)}\mathsf{N}^{(r)}\mathsf{U}^{(r)*}; (61)

With this form, while it is still true that ùñ†=ùñ≤B(r)+ùñ≤C(r)+Œ©B(r)+Œ©C(r)ùñ†subscriptsuperscriptùñ≤ùëüùêµsubscriptsuperscriptùñ≤ùëüùê∂subscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùëüùêµsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùëüùê∂\mathsf{A}=\mathsf{S}^{(r)}_{B}+\mathsf{S}^{(r)}_{C}+\mathsf{\Omega}^{(r)}_{{B}}+\mathsf{\Omega}^{(r)}_{{C}} and ‚Äñùñ≤A‚Äñ2=‚Äñùñ≤B(r)‚Äñ2+‚Äñùñ≤C(r)‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùñ≤ùê¥2superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptùñ≤ùëüùêµ2superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptùñ≤ùëüùê∂2||\mathsf{S}_{{A}}||^{2}=||\mathsf{S}^{(r)}_{{B}}||^{2}+||\mathsf{S}^{(r)}_{{C}}||^{2}, a difference emerges when one considers the additive property for ‚ÄñŒ©A‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptsans-serif-Œ©ùê¥2||\mathsf{\Omega}_{{A}}||^{2} and its constituent rotation tensors. Given the importance of enstrophy for the analyses in this paper, this explains why we adopt the complex variant of the transform throughout.
